fields.title: What are opioids?
fields.content:
Opioids are a type of drug that includes heroin and prescription pain medications.

 

 

[Button] Click *here* to see examples of opioids [

  • heroin
  • Percocet
  • Vicodin
  • oxycodone
  • Oxycontin
  • Dilaudid
  • Fentanyl]

fields.title: Would I benefit from treatment?
fields.content: [break up questions into more pages]

fields.title: How do you treat opioid use disorder?
fields.content: We know from research that medications have the most success for treating opioid use disorder.

fields.title: What are my choices for treatment?
fields.content:
Medications have the most success for treating opioid use disorder. These are the 3 options proven to help: 

(1) [Button] Methadone [This medication reduces withdrawal and cravings, You take it as a liquid everyday. In the first 3 months you will need to take it in a specialty clinic, but if you are stable you can take it at home]

(2) [Button] Buprenorphine (also known as Suboxone, Subutex, or others) [This medication reduces withdrawals and cravings. You take it as a dissolvable tab or pill, usually everyday. After visiting your doctor and getting a stable dose within the first few days, you can take this medicine at home]

(3) [Button] Naltrexone injection (also known as Vivitrol)  [This medication does not reduce withdrawals - you will receive other medications to help during detox before you start. It can reduce cravings a small amount You take it as an injection, every month, in a clinic]

[Question: which medications have you tried?]

fields.title: Medication Differences
fields.content:
This chapter explains differences among your treatment options. 

Many patients find that even though treatment has side effects, costs, and requirements, that using opioids of addiction (such as heroin), have similar or worse side effects, costs, and requirements. They find life overall to be easier on medications.

fields.title: How Long is Treatment?
fields.content:
Most patients need to stay in treatment for at least 3-5 years. 

If you have had opioid use disorder for a longer time, you may need an even longer time to heal.

fields.title: Would I benefit from treatment?
fields.content: [output results are missing]

fields.title: How does treatment help me?
fields.content:
Treatment with medication will help you

* feel better
* save your life
* improve your health 
* improve your day-to-day life abilities

fields.title: Medications improve your health
fields.content:
Medications will improve your mental and physical health. Treatment will

[Button] Mood [Medications improve your mood by decreasing anxiety and depression, and helping you feel more even]

[Button] Infection [Medications can lower injection behavior and improve your immune system, which means less risk for infections]

[Button] Get Care [Medications can stabilize your life so you can get medical and psychological care you need]

fields.title: Methadone
fields.content:
Methadone is a liquid taken by mouth, once a day.
 

In the first 3 months, go to a clinic every day to take your medication. As you get stable, you may be able to take medication at home.

 

This medicine helps you feel better by treating withdrawal and cravings.

fields.title: Buprenorphine
fields.content:
Buprenorphine forms include Suboxone (dissolving tab) or Subutex (pill). It is usually taken by mouth, once a day.

In the beginning you will need to stop using opioids like heroin for several hours, then you can start this medicine. You will go to a clinic to get started and for check-ups, but you can take this medication at home. 

This medicine helps you feel better by treating withdrawal and cravings.

fields.title: Naltrexone
fields.content:
Naltrexone is an injection that is also called Vivitrol. It is taken as an injection, in the buttocks, once a month.

The pill version does not work as well for opioid disorder, only for alcohol.

You must stop using any opioids for at least 7 days before starting this medication. You can get the injection in the clinic every month.

This medicine does not treat withdrawals; it helps a little bit with cravings. Instead you will get different medicines during the first 7 days to help with detox. This medicine blocks opioids like heroin.

fields.title: What is true of all medications?
fields.content:
Medication options will help you: 

Click to see more info

* [feel better]
* [save your life]
* [improve your health] 
* [improve your day-to-day life abilities] 

[feel better: Medications calm the body’s system as it gets used to being away from the drug. Two medication options (methadone and buprenorphine) treat *withdrawal* symptoms and decrease *cravings.* [Inline clicking] *withdrawal* [Withdrawal symptoms can start several hours after your body has used an opioid. It can feel like a very severe flu, with fatigue, seating, nausea, diarrhea, and other symptoms.]
[Inline clicking] *cravings* [Cravings are a strong desire to take the drug. These are strongest during the first several days of stopping the opioid, and slowly decrease with time. However they can last several months or longer.]

Naltrexone does not* treat withdrawals or cravings, but other treatment can be provided]


[save your life: Getting stable on medication means you will be safer from death. Medications protect you from overdose death and life-threatening infections.If you have other medical conditions (like heart disease, HIV, or depression), medications help you get stable to get the care you need.]


[improve your health: Medications will improve your mental and physical health. Treatment will improve

[Inline] Mood [Medications improve your mood by decreasing anxiety and depression, and helping you feel more even]

[inline] Infection [Medications can lower injection behavior and improve your immune system, which means less risk for infections]

[inline] Get Care [Medications can stabilize your life so you can get medical and psychological care you need]] 

 

[improve your day-to-day life abilities: Medication lowers your risk of arrest and legal problems. It stabilizes you so you can connect to your family, relationships, and work. ]

fields.title: Benefits of Medications
fields.content:
You can compare different medications and no medication. The bigger the solid circle, the bigger the benefit for that option and category. 

Click on the row to learn more.

fields.title: How Do I End Treatment?
fields.content: If you and your doctor decide it is time to end treatment, this can be done slowly to avoid withdrawal symptoms.

fields.title: What happens if I stop treatment on my own?
fields.content: If treatment is stopped quickly, on your own or because of things outside your control, you can have withdrawal symptoms.

fields.title: Opioid Use Disorder
fields.content:
Opioid Use Disorder is sometimes called Addiction. 

It is a medical illness of the brain, one that can be managed successfully with treatment.

fields.title: Chronic Conditions Relapse and Remit
fields.content:
Opioid use disorder can relapse and remit.

This means that you may get better, but then start using opioids again (relapse), and have to restart or adjust your treatment to become stable again (remit).

This also happens in other medical conditions, like high blood pressure. 

 

[Question: have you previously been on treatment then stopped? 

How many times have you had treatment before?]

fields.title: Opioid use becomes a problem over time
fields.content:
Over time, some people need to continue taking these drugs just to feel normal, even if it causes problems or even if it takes over their life.

They can find it difficult to quit on their own.

fields.title: Medications can save your life
fields.content:
Getting stable on medication means you will be safer from death. 

[Button] Decrease Risks [Medications help you protect yourself from overdose death and life-threatening infections.]

[Button] Get Care [If you have other medical conditions (like heart disease, HIV, or depression), medications help you get stable to get the care you need.]

fields.title: Medications improve your day-to-day life abilities
fields.content:
Treatment lowers your risk of arrest and legal problems. 

Treatment stabilizes you so you can connect to your family, relationships, and work.

fields.title: How do I start treatment?
fields.content:
Each medication has a different way to start. Click to find out how each medication is started. 

[Button] Methadone [you can start right away]

[Button] Buprenorphine [you must wait 6-12 hours after using before starting if you use opioids like heroin]

[Button] Naltrexone [you must stop using any opioids for 7 days before starting. Your doctor can help you feel better during this time with other medications to treat your withdrawal.]

fields.title: Where do I get the medications?
fields.content:
In the first three months, getting the medications will be different. Click to find out how they are different. 

[buttons]

[Button] Methadone [In the beginning must come into a specialized clinic almost every day to receive your dose. If you are stable after 3 months you will be able to take medications at home] 

[Button] Buprenorphine [In the beginning you go to clinic to get started. Within 1-3 days, this medication can be picked up from the pharmacy and taken at home. You may need to come to clinic every week in the beginning to make sure the dose is right and that you are stable] 

[Button] Naltrexone [once you are stable on this medication, you come into the clinic once a month to get an injection]

fields.title: How does the treatment get in my body?
fields.content:
Each medication is taken into the body in different ways. 

[Button] Methadone [this is a liquid that you swallow by mouth every day]

[Button] Buprenorphine [usually this is a tab that dissolves in the mouth or is a pill that is swallowed by mouth every day]

[Button] Naltrexone [this is an injection in the buttock every month]

fields.title: Common Side Effects
fields.content:
All medications can have side effects. Everyone can be affected differently. Most people will experience similar or worse side effects from opioids of addiciton, such as heroin. Click to read the most common effects of medications.

[Button] Methadone [sleeping problems, weight gain, constipation, sexual side effects [graphic: icon vs infographics (3 out of 12 etc)] 

[Button] Buprenorphine [sleeping problems, headaches]

[Button] Naltrexone [irritation at the injection site]

fields.title: Cost
fields.content:
Public insurance (Husky) covers all of medication options, usually with very little cost to you. Private insurance usually covers all medication options, but the cost depends on the insurance. Most people find medications cheaper than using opioids of addiction (which can cost $1800 a month or more) Click to see costs of medications with no insurance. 

[Button] Methadone [$300 per month]

[Button] Buprenorphine [$200 per month]

[Button] Naltrexone [$1350 per month]

fields.title: What is the intensity and duration of withdrawal if I stop?
fields.content:
If you and your doctor decide it is time to end treatment, this can be done slowly to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Stopping some medications suddenly on your own can cause withdrawal symptoms [button: withdrawal symptom def]. Click to read more about each medication 

[Button] Methadone [withdrawal is as intense as opioids like heroin, but lasts longer, for 6 weeks]

[Button] Buprenorphine [withdrawal is less intense than opioids like heroin, and lasts 1 week]

[Button] Naltrexone [there is no withdrawal]

fields.title: What is the risk of death if I stop treatment on my own?
fields.content:
Stopping treatment suddenly means your risk of death goes up, especially from overdose if you start using again.

For all treatment, the risk of death is especially high in the first 2 weeks after you stop treatment, then goes down over time. There is a high risk of relapse to opioid use like heroin.

When it is time to end treatment, work closely with your doctor to monitor how you are doing.

fields.title: Opioid Use Disorder is a Chronic Condition
fields.content:
Opioid use disorder is a chronic disease, similar to diabetes and asthma. That means it can take time to get stable and for the brain to heal. 

 

 

[question: how long have you had issues with opioid dependence?]

fields.title: Medications will help you feel better
fields.content:
Medications calm the body’s system as it gets used to being away from the drug. Two medication options treat *withdrawal* symptoms and decrease *cravings.*

[Inline clicking] *withdrawal* [Withdrawal symptoms can start several hours after your body has used an opioid. It can feel like a very severe flu, with fatigue, seating, nausea, diarrhea, and other symptoms.]
[Inline clicking] *cravings* [Cravings are a strong desire to take the drug. These are strongest during the first several days of stopping the opioid, and slowly decrease with time. However they can last several months or longer.]

fields.title: What is true of all medications?
fields.content:
Medications must be taken at the right dose, which you can figure out with your doctor

Most patients need 3-5 years to let the brain heal, some need longer.

fields.title: Medication Options: Summary
fields.content: [ new graphical chart here ]

fields.title: Is treatment worth it?
fields.content:
Most people find the benefits of treatment is worth the side effects, costs and requirements.

Patients often find there are less side effects, costs, and difficulties for treatment compared to using opioids of addiction. 

In this section we will also compare treatment options to continuing to use opioids like heroin.

fields.title: Medication Differences: summary
fields.content: [ summary chart ]

fields.title: Stopping treatment can increase risk of death
fields.content: After you stop using opioids or medications, your tolerance to opioids go down - that means your body is not used to the opioids anymore. That means if there is relapse and you use again, there is a higher risk of overdose.

fields.title: Stopping medications: Summary
fields.content: [ new table ]

fields.title: The Ups and Downs of Treating Opioid Use Disorder
fields.content:
Recovery often has ups and downs - you might be be better for a long time, then have a relapse. This is very common. It may even happen multiple times. 

The good news is that even if you have a relapse, treatment can get you better again, and help you remain stable over time.

fields.title: What should I know for deciding on treatment?
fields.content:
It is important for you to have all the information so you can make a decision that works for you. In this section we will discuss

- how to start a treatment

- where to get treatment

- how treatment gets in the body

- side effects

- cost

We will also compare treatment to continuing use of opioids of addiction, like heroin.

fields.title: Intro: Learning about Opioid Use Disorder and Treatment
fields.content:
This decision aid will help you learn which treatment for opioid use disorder is right for you

The goal  is to help you understand your choices so you can work with your doctor to find which option is best for you. 

Some words are highlighted. Click on those words to learn more information. 

When you are ready to move to the next page, click "NEXT."

You can keep track of what options and concerns are most important to you in the side menu. 

[ big arrow to link ] 

When you are done, you can print these notes to discuss with your doctor.

fields.title: What are medication differences?
fields.content:
Methadone and buprenorphine help withdrawals, but naltrexone does not (you will get other medications to help during detox). 

We will discuss more differences in the next chapter.

fields.title: Take these to your doctor
fields.content: [ output quiz ]

fields.title: What is opioid use disorder?
fields.content:
Opioid Use Disorder (also called addiction) is a medical illness of the brain, one that can be managed successfully with treatment.

Opioids are a type of drug that includes heroin and prescription pain medications. Examples

Over time, some people need to continue taking these drugs just to feel normal, even if it causes problems or even if it takes over their life. They can find it difficult to quit on their own.

Opioid use disorder is a chronic disease, similar to diabetes and asthma. That means it can take time to get stable and for the brain to heal. Most patients need at least 3-5 years of treatment to let the brain heal, and some need much longer. You will work with your doctor to decide what is right for you

Similar to other medical conditions, you may get better, but then start using opioids again (relapse), and have to restart or adjust your treatment to become stable again (remit).Recovery can have ups and downs - you might be be better for a long time, then have a relapse. This is very common. It may even happen multiple times. 

The good news is that even if you have a relapse, treatment can get you better again, and help you remain stable over time. 

[Examples: heroin, Percocet, Vicodin, oxycodone, Oxycontin, Dilaudid, Fentanyl]

fields.title: How long is Treatment?
fields.content: Because opioid use disorder is a chronic condition (like asthma or diabetes) most patients need at least 3-5 years to let the brain heal, and some need much longer. You will work with your doctor to decide what is right for you.

fields.title: How does treatment affect withdrawal?
fields.content:
Methadone and buprenorphine help withdrawals

Naltrexone does not (you will get other medications and support to help during detox).

fields.title: How does treatment make me feel?
fields.content:
Methadone and buprenorphine help withdrawals and cravings. 

Naltrexone does not (you will get other medications and support to help during detox).

data.text: We know from research that medications have the most success for treating opioid use disorder.

This decision aid will help you learn which treatment for opioid use disorder is right for you

The goal  is to help you understand your choices so you can work with your doctor to find which option is best for you. 

Some words are highlighted. Click on those words to learn more information. 

When you are ready to move to the next page, click "NEXT."

You can keep track of what options and concerns are most important to you in the side menu. 

[ big arrow to link ] 

When you are done, you can print these notes to discuss with your doctor.

Opioid Use Disorder is sometimes called Addiction. 

It is a medical illness of the brain, one that can be managed successfully with treatment.

Because opioid use disorder is a chronic condition (like asthma or diabetes) most patients need at least 3-5 years to let the brain heal, and some need much longer. You will work with your doctor to decide what is right for you.

This chapter explains differences among your treatment options. 

Many patients find that even though treatment has side effects, costs, and requirements, that using opioids of addiction (such as heroin), have similar or worse side effects, costs, and requirements. They find life overall to be easier on medications.

Most patients need to stay in treatment for at least 3-5 years. 

If you have had opioid use disorder for a longer time, you may need an even longer time to heal.
[ output quiz ]

Opioids are a type of drug that includes heroin and prescription pain medications.

 

 

[Button] Click *here* to see examples of opioids [

  • heroin
  • Percocet
  • Vicodin
  • oxycodone
  • Oxycontin
  • Dilaudid
  • Fentanyl]

Medications have the most success for treating opioid use disorder. These are the 3 options proven to help: 

(1) [Button] Methadone [This medication reduces withdrawal and cravings, You take it as a liquid everyday. In the first 3 months you will need to take it in a specialty clinic, but if you are stable you can take it at home]

(2) [Button] Buprenorphine (also known as Suboxone, Subutex, or others) [This medication reduces withdrawals and cravings. You take it as a dissolvable tab or pill, usually everyday. After visiting your doctor and getting a stable dose within the first few days, you can take this medicine at home]

(3) [Button] Naltrexone injection (also known as Vivitrol)  [This medication does not reduce withdrawals - you will receive other medications to help during detox before you start. It can reduce cravings a small amount You take it as an injection, every month, in a clinic]

[Question: which medications have you tried?]

Treatment with medication will help you

* feel better
* save your life
* improve your health 
* improve your day-to-day life abilities
If you and your doctor decide it is time to end treatment, this can be done slowly to avoid withdrawal symptoms.

Each medication has a different way to start. Click to find out how each medication is started. 

[Button] Methadone [you can start right away]

[Button] Buprenorphine [you must wait 6-12 hours after using before starting if you use opioids like heroin]

[Button] Naltrexone [you must stop using any opioids for 7 days before starting. Your doctor can help you feel better during this time with other medications to treat your withdrawal.]

It is important for you to have all the information so you can make a decision that works for you. In this section we will discuss

- how to start a treatment

- where to get treatment

- how treatment gets in the body

- side effects

- cost

We will also compare treatment to continuing use of opioids of addiction, like heroin.

Over time, some people need to continue taking these drugs just to feel normal, even if it causes problems or even if it takes over their life.

They can find it difficult to quit on their own.

Naltrexone is an injection that is also called Vivitrol. It is taken as an injection, in the buttocks, once a month.

The pill version does not work as well for opioid disorder, only for alcohol.

You must stop using any opioids for at least 7 days before starting this medication. You can get the injection in the clinic every month.

This medicine does not treat withdrawals; it helps a little bit with cravings. Instead you will get different medicines during the first 7 days to help with detox. This medicine blocks opioids like heroin.

If you and your doctor decide it is time to end treatment, this can be done slowly to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Stopping some medications suddenly on your own can cause withdrawal symptoms [button: withdrawal symptom def]. Click to read more about each medication 

[Button] Methadone [withdrawal is as intense as opioids like heroin, but lasts longer, for 6 weeks]

[Button] Buprenorphine [withdrawal is less intense than opioids like heroin, and lasts 1 week]

[Button] Naltrexone [there is no withdrawal]

Methadone and buprenorphine help withdrawals, but naltrexone does not (you will get other medications to help during detox). 

We will discuss more differences in the next chapter.

You can compare different medications and no medication. The bigger the solid circle, the bigger the benefit for that option and category. 

Click on the row to learn more.
[ summary chart ]

data.label: Did you ever need to use more opioids to get the same high as when you first started using opioids?
Did the idea of missing a fix (or dose) ever make you anxious or worried?
In the morning, did you ever use opioids to keep from feeling "dope sick" or did you ever feel "dope sick"?
Did you worry about your use of opioids?
Did you find it difficult to stop or not use opioids?
Did you ever need to spend a lot of time/energy on finding opioids or recovering from feeling high?
Did you ever miss important things like doctor's appointments, family/friend activities, or other things because of opioids?
